reviewText: Unless you want to be freaked out do not watch this on off a projector at midnight.  What can I say that hasnt already been said.  If you like zombies you have to watch this.  It is excellent, well written and will keep you on the edge of your seat.  As stated before, maybe watching it in 100 inches at midnight wasnt the best idea but what the heck.  You only live once, or is that twice.  These are zombies and are not infected as far as I can tell.  That being said, try it, you will like it!  There are 6 episodes and are only a 1.99 each.  45 minute episodes for the first one and 30 or so for the last ones.  So your total outlay will be about 12 bucks for well over 150 minutes of zombie goodness.  2 hours and 30 minutes of fun!  Well worth the price of admission.

reviewText: Originally broadcast on Channel Four in the UK over five nights in the run-up to Halloween, 2008, "Dead Set" is frankly the most hypnotically accomplished piece of work to appear in the tired old genre of zombie horror since Max Brooks similarly superbWorld War Z: An Oral History of the Zombie Warwas published several years ago.The brainchild of British media-satirist, Charlie Brooker, the series follows the experiences of a group of "Big Brother" contestants who are unwittingly plunged into the horrific reality of attempting to survive amidst the nightmarish cycle of cannibalism, violence and resurrection so familiar to fans of George A. Romero. However, Brooker being Brooker, all tropes and conventions of the genre are eschewed in favour of a thematic tone which is at once deeply realistic and subversively satirical; one can view the entire series as a bilious broadside aimed at our celebrity-obsessed, media-saturated culture and in many ways it is the legitimate heir to Romero's consumerist satire,Dawn of the Dead (Ultimate Edition)(vastly more so than that director's own deeply unsatisfying attempt to satirise modern media,George A. Romero's Diary of the Dead).Director Yann Demange juxtaposes the colourful hyper-reality of the reality TV segments which open the story with a grey, desaturated, washed-out look which represents the "real-world" (and which perfectly compliments the sense of depressing ordinariness with which the survivors come to view their situation), and the cast imbue the characters - who could've functioned as little more than archetypes - with a profoundly flawed sense of helplessness and humanity; I strongly suspect that well-meaning but ineffectual contestant, Joplin (Kevin Eldon) and deeply unpleasant but pragmatically realistic producer, Patrick (Andy Nyman) embody the left/right brain personas of Brooker as a commentator within the piece (and it must be said, as deeply caustic as Patrick is, he remains by far my favourite character and he certainly gets the best lines). The sense of reality that pervades the series is also immensely strengthened by the presence of actual "Big Brother UK" presenter Davina McCall who appears in a superb cameo.This is a brilliant, uncompromising piece of television which probably tells more truth about the state of today's junk-food/junk-television/junk-everything obsessed culture than most people will be comfortable to admitting. But then, like our erstwhile survivors, one imagines that it's exactly the kind of people who sit in denial about the state of the world who really 'would' spend a speculative zombie holocaust hiding in a closet bemoaning the loss of Egg McMuffins, "Lost" and their iphone rather than doing something constructive about their own survival.Highly recommended.
summary: "Yeah, Well That's People For You, Innit? They're All Animals."

reviewText: Odds are you hadn't heard of this clever horror gem. DEAD SET is a British television mini-series that documents an instance of zombie apocalypse. Running at approximately 141 minutes and broken up into five episodes, DEAD SET first aired on the E4 network from October 27 to 31, 2008. And it is riveting stuff. It is harrowing and darkly comic and, most importantly, doesn't condescend to its viewers. It merges zombies with reality television. It's another kick-in-the-arse commentary on conformity within our society and our fixation on pretend televised sensationalism. It's a wicked satire, brought about by exec. producer/writer Charlie Brooker's scathing wit.I'd never seen the Big Brother show. And, frankly, I despise those who fawn over them trumped-up celebrities. It's disturbing to me that in the UK, where it originated, Big Brother is even more popular. (I guess having a damn cool accent doesn't necessarily equate to sophistication.) DEAD SET tracks the cast and crew of the obnoxious Big Brother reality show, and for those who are in the dark as I am, its premise goes like this: Contestants selected for their inability to get along with each other are plonked in a confined space and each week are voted off the show by the viewers. As DEAD SET opens, the contestants and the production crew are so wrapped up with the shooting of the latest episode that news of a cataclysmic national emergency pass them by.I saw this mini-series with a cousin who is a reality show fiend (and, yes, I despise him for it). But he filled me in with some background material. Such as that the in-film presenter, Davina McCall, is the real-life UK Big Brother presenter. And that the UK version of the Big Brother house is a fortified compound on the Elstree studios lot. Wire fences lace the compound's perimeter. It is regularly patrolled by security to keep the public out. Apparently, the set designers of DEAD SET have reproduced the Big Brother house to an almost exact likeness. Meaning that those familiar with the show and the house's layout will get that extra thrill. But for the purposes of serving the zombie narrative, the compound and those barricaded within amp up the genre's often used siege element.The ensemble cast is uniformly solid, even the actors relegated to the stereotype roles (the hot bimbo, the creepy guy, the hunk, the street-savvy homie...). But the two standouts are Andy Nyman as the absolutely hateful producer "Patrick" (he gets the best dialogue) and Jaime Winstone as "Kelly," the harassed production runner/gofer and eventual plucky heroine. Kelly provides the narrative thread. She's our point-of-view character. I appreciate that Kelly does the sensible thing even in the midst of blind panic. She retrieves her weapon (How many times have we seen someone absent-mindedly discard their weapon?). Before exiting a room, she peeks under the door to determine safe passage. It's gratifying to see someone who isn't prone to typical horror movie stupidity. I do question that Kelly and several others, in such short time, become such deadeye shooters.There's satisfaction for the gorehounds. DEAD SET may be a television mini-series but it doesn't stinge on gore and blood and brutal kills. It's got more-than-decent production values. And, yes, for viewers of gentler persuasion, there is profanity. Because "Yikes!" is not an appropriate expletive when you're being targeted by the undead. However, taking a panic dump in a bin IS very much appropriate.All five episodes are on one All-Region disc. Bonus stuff is as follows:From Episode One:- "Davina McKill" - An interview with reality game show presenter Davina McCall while she has her zombie make-up put on, followed by a behind-the-scenes look at one of her zombie scenes (00:06:51 minutes)- "SFX: You've Got to Get Them in the Head" - the f/x crew looks at the fire extinguisher as a zombie killing device (00:02:45)- 2 Deleted/Extended ScenesFrom Episode Two:- "Interview with director Yann Demange" (00:04:21)- "On Set with DEAD SET - interviews with the cast (00:06:13)From Episode Three:- "Interview with exec. producer/writer Charlie Brooker" and if you can't guess whom Patrick the Producer is based on after this interview, well... (00:06:02)- "SFX: Head Shots" - With stunt performer John street who plays a zombie whose head is shot up by a copper (00:02:09)From Episode Four:- "House of the Dead" - Charlie Brooker gives an acerbic tour of the faux Big Brother set (00:05:06)- "SFX: Davina" - Davina McCall's zombification (00:00:58 seconds)- One Deleted/Extended SceneFrom Episode Five:- "I Am Patrick, Hear Me Roar" - Interview with actor Andy Nyman (00:03:52)- "Army of the Dead" - For the climactic zombie mob scenes, zombie extras recruited thru the Internet work thru the early morning hours (00:03:35)- "SFX: Patrick G!ves Head" - Patrick gets what's coming to him (00:04:11)- 2 Deleted/Extended Scenes (including how Pippa bites it)

reviewText: My zombie bar is set high, but Dead Set far exceeded my expectations, especially for a television miniseries. A worldwide zombie outbreak has left the contestants on the UK Big Brother reality show oblivious to the horrors outside, and safe (for the moment) in their locked down "house" on a studio lot. Contestants consist of the cliched personalities typical of these shows: the dumb jock, the blonde Barbie, the sassy gay guy, the creepy outcast, etc. The series is a perfect blend of suspense, horror, and comedy. Yes, comedy. The scenes between the loathsome producer, Patrick, and Pippa, the unbelievably stupid Big Brother contestant, will have you laughing out loud.The survivors eventually need to make a decision: do they stay trapped in the house that is at least somewhat secure, despite the hungry zombies massing outside the studio gates, or do they make a run for it, not knowing where to go or how far the infestation has spread? Not surprisingly, the group has differing opinions, and a couple of idiotic moves with catastrophic consequences, forces their hands. As the outbreak catches up to our survivors, you will be rooting for some to escape, and hoping that others (Patrick and Pippa come to mind) become zombie food.As the zombie attacks started halfway through the first episode, I started to worry a bit that all of the dark lighting and quick edits were a sign of very cheap special effects. Not too worry though - things really picked up by episode 2 and stayed that way to the end, so stick with it!And speaking of the end....just WOW. It was absolute perfection.
summary: Best zombie show I've ever seeen

reviewText: This TV mini-series really gets the zombie genre better than a lot of zombie films do. A great concept that was surprisingly well executed. Not sure how this got produced, must have been a fortuitous fluke, but the film-makers really captured the nail-biting, claustrophobic fear like only the best zombie films have pulled off. Sure, one or two characters are a bit over the top but I guess that is a prerequisite British TV, right?
summary: One of the Best Zombie Films and its from TV!

reviewText: The inevitable zombie apocalypse never comes at a convenient time. People stuck at work or stuck in traffic or stuck in the tubes or stuck in the suburbs or stuck outside the pub. Dramatically, that works nicely so instead of hunkering down and waiting it out, people are forced to move around through a completely inhospitable environment to get to where they want to be. What could be more inhospitable to safety and sanity than a reality TV show set?In Dead Set, a short series for Channel 4 (it's five episodes representing about two and a half hours running time), the British version of Big Brother is having an eviction night, meaning one of the contestants is about to be voted out of the house. We see both the contestants and the behind-the-sceens production crew, though the story is focused on Kelly, possibly the lowliest employee on the set. She's the girl who has to get the coffees and the sandwiches and whatever random things the producers want. And nobody remembers her name, especially the insufferable producer. She's been seeing one of the guys on the set, who apparently has dated just about every female on the crew. Kelly has a real boyfriend in the outside world but she's a little stressed out and confused about her life.The producer is stressed because, as they come to broadcast time, news reports of riots breaking out across England are taking over all the stations. Will they be pre-empted by real-life drama? He uses his rudeness, bravado, and arrogance  to keep  the crew and the housemates ready to go. The show does go on, but the zombie invasion comes right after the station break. Zombies make it into the production facility but not into the sealed-off Big Brother house. The housemates are completely unaware that the rest of the world is falling apart. Of course, they are clueless and narcissistic to begin with, so hilarity and horror ensues.The premise is well-thought out. Kelly's ability to scrounge quickly translates to survival skills in the new zombie paradigm. The producer is also a survivor, having guided many reality shows and manipulated many people into doing his bidding. He gets locked in a green room with someone while Kelly has to face the contestants incredulity and incompetence. A side story follows the boyfriend as he tries to make it back to the set.The zombie gore is full-on and not for the faint of stomach. The satire is also pitch-black and was a little too dependent on familiarity with Big Brother and reality TV (they had actual on-screen talent from Big Brother like Davina McCall). I felt like I missed some of the jests and jabs at the genre. I saw moments that could have been funnier if I'd had the bigger context. The obnoxious yet cunning producer is an interesting if unlikeable character. Kelly and her boyfriend are likeable and keep you hoping for a good outcome. Yeah, right...If you're a fan of reality TV like Big Brother and zombies a la George Romero, you will enjoy this show a lot.
summary: More horror than comedy; pitch black satire ahead!

reviewText: A terrific sick joke--"Dead Set" has finally arrived on U.S. soil. It begs the question of what took so long? I caught wind of this unique entry into zombie lore a couple of years ago and have been awaiting its arrival in America ever since. Still not slated for a DVD release (as of 11/3/10--why, please?), the five action packed episodes were finally brought to light on this side of the pond in a televised broadcast by IFC. This British miniseries is an inspired combination, to be sure, pitting the mind numbing shallowness of reality television against the single minded voraciousness of the flesh eating undead. A greater concept simply could not have been devised, but that the idea was brought to fruition successfully is a big cheers to everyone involved."Dead Set," for all its satirical pleasures, also offers nicely built tension and well done gore. Set in the "Big Brother" studio on a live eviction night no less--things begin to go haywire when unexpected guests start to show up. And in the immortal words of "Entertainment Weekly"--"Best. Eviction. Episode. Ever." The "Big Brother" house is populated by the expected character archetypes that pass for reality show contestants, but they are blissfully unaware of the carnage surrounding them. After the initial mayhem, several live people outside the house are still kicking away as well. There is the show's outspoken producer ("Dead Set's" most delightfully overwrought performance!), a plucky production assistant, and the P.A.'s boyfriend who is attempting to get to the studio. Soon all survivors must band together for a final confrontation.The episodes of "Dead Set" (especially 2-5) are fast and furious fun. You chuckle at the characters even as the show really has no goal to develop them beyond their initial stereotypes. That doesn't mean you won't like them--it just means you won't get to know them in much depth. I loved the most relentless zombie--the "Big Brother" hostess and, as I mentioned earlier, the show's producer is a hoot. "Dead Set" follows conventional zombie guidelines--although these are the fast variety of creatures that have been popping up more frequently (I prefer my undead to meander not sprint!). Brutal and graphic, this plays for real horror and is not simply a comedy--that was perhaps the biggest surprise for me. I got my fill of gruesome bloodshed and appreciated the undercurrent of effective satire and humor. Great fun overall. KGHarris, 11/10.
summary: To Quote "Entertainment Weekly"--This "Big Brother" Horror Show Can Be Summed Up In Four Words: Best. Eviction. Episode. Ever.

reviewText: I bought this U.K. Pal DVD for a Region-Free DVD-Player I bought specifically to play all the great European (but mostly British) releases that aren't yet available in the U.S.However, guess what - this actually plays in my regular DVD Region 1 player also.  Not that I would have known if I hadn't tried it out of curiosity.  The show is great right up until the poorly written last 10 minutes or so where people do ridiculous things for no good reason.  But, the ending aside the chase scenes and tension-building are very good, much like '28 Days Later' as are the Zombies, who are all fitter in death than they are in life.

reviewText: This was shown finally , unedited on american tv in 2010 on a cable channel. why it took that long is beyond me. This show is a great zombie show that ties into 'big brother' the 'reality' tv series. As much as I loved this series I can't say the same about the bb series it's spun off of. This is like a george romero zombie flick because it lampoons the shallowness of the people in reality tv land. And in the way hordes of zombies keep coming because this was 'like a religion to them' , this is a borrowed idea from the original classic 'dawn of the dead' where they kept coming to the mall. In this one the zombies move faster like the newer version of 'dawn of the dead' or the modern classic "28 days later'.  There is humour in this like a romero flick and lots of gore and cussing too. The characters are generally not very likeable , there are a few decent folks in this one but that's not the point , life is filled with self important narcisistic people and they really exist in show biz so that's all the more realistic. Ironically the great new zombie series on amc 'the walking dead' was on at the same time! not to worry that one will be around for a while because it's awesome. This one is worth owning though , it moves fast and delivers in dread and gore and doesn't give you a cheap ending either.

reviewText: It's easy to be jaded about zombie movies.  After all, there's very little that hasn't already been done - slow zombies, fast ones, zombies that represent the dirty masses. You name it, Romero has produced it. Zombies have become old hat.But then there's Dead Set.Dead Set is nominally about the British version of Big Brother, which spawned the version here in the States. Dead Set's portrayal of the ugly world of reality television is the world we already think we know - jaded, cynical, and pedestrian. Dead Set's reality is sadly not that much of a surprise.What is a surprise is how viscerally nasty Dead Set becomes when the zombies show up. Most zombie tales are less about the zombies and more about the survivors, and Dead Set is no exception.  What better place to hole up than the Big Brother house, dedicated to feeding and sheltering a bunch of narcissistic reality parasites?There are no likable characters in Dead Set.  In fact, the characters work hard to outdo each other by being as unlikable as possible, because in the new reality of the zombie apocalypse, unlikable people survive. Utterly amoral producer (Andy Nyman) barks commands at minion Kelly (Jaime Winstone), the closest thing we have to a protagonist.  The rest of the contestants are stereotypes: the ditzy one, the loose one, the dumb jock, the spoiled one...we've seen every one of these sordid tropes on display since the dawn of reality shows. And they are all here to die.Director Yann Demange has fun with this reality show within a reality show.  Are you disgusted more by the cruelty of reality television or by zombies? Are the masses of angry fans that much different from brain-hungry reanimated corpses? And if you're watching...does that make you one of them?Demange has the answers, and none of them are very complementary - to the state of reality television, to its viewers, and most of all, us. Unlike reality television which reinforces our comforting dichotomies of heroes and villains, Dead Set is only too happy to reinforce a real reality: in a zombie apocalypse, most of us wouldn't have what it takes to survive. Drawing parallels with Dawn of the Dead's anti-consumerist messages and 28 Days Later's fast zombies, Dead Set creates a surprisingly fresh zombie tale.

reviewText: I will never understand the U.S. dvd market.  The U.K. has the best releases, whether it is Laurel and Hardy, Creepshow, The Hammer Films, Psycho, etc.  There has been so many things not released, or half assed by the studios I had to purchase a region free dvd player just to get the films and sets I wanted.  Dead Set is a great zombie mini series.  Running time is 2 1/2 hours long, though it could have really been fleshed out even more.  The short form of the story has the contestants of the Big Brother reality show locked away in their house while the world falls into chaos very quickly as the dead begin to rise.  By the time the contestants realize what is going on, it is too late.  They are trapped while the world falls down around them.  Terrific British zombie tale and hopefully since it was mentioned in EW by Stephen King, it may get enough buzz to get it released over here.  Decent zombie makeup and good gore.  Camera is very quick when the zombies attack, and the zombies are the running versions.  Great dvd.

reviewText: Very happy that,I,purchased an all region DVD player so i could get films and this British Tele-miniseries that is ONE of the BEST Zombie shows yet! The best way to describe DEAD-SET is,Night Of The Living Dead Meets Shaun Of The Dead.While their is an underlying sense of satire/comedy mixed with an reality show background,the makers of this horror epic never forget to go deeper into the realm of horror/thriller to provide what essentially becomes like a roller coaster ride experience for the fans in whom no doubt that the director intended this show for.There are only a few movies that have been made featuring Fast-Running ZOMBIES,Nightmare CityA.K.A.City of the Walking Dead1980,28 days later,28 weeks later,the remake of Romeros ,Day of the Dead,the remake of Dawn of the Dead and also most recent,Devils Playground,that is another exellent U.K.film.Don't forget about Rec or Rec 2 or the upcoming prequel and third sequel to those thrillers that are on the drawing boards or The Greek film Evil:to kako and its sequel featuring Billy Zane that should soon be available!Dead-set is an example of how much ALIVE! the ZOMBIE genre has become.And oh yeah,the ending of this one reminds me of the ironic ending of Romero's Night of the Living Dead. The ending of Dead-Set brought tears to my eyes and that is the first time Any Zombie flick has ever moved me emotionally. A must-see for Zombie fans and the DVD Dead-Set is full of many deleted scenes and special features as well as being as pristine a visual copy as i have seen yet.As an American,I,must say,the UNITED KINGDOM and The British are giving Hollywood ,a BLOODY run for their money in terms of Film-making!

reviewText: Check your region on your DVD player before ordering - the US version is lackluster at best, and was not printed in large quantity. If you have a regionless DVD player, go with that option)Big Brother is one of those things that seems to live large overseas. And it was indeed living large on this set - quite a bit larger than most shows the U.S. has. People were outside the big Brother home waiting to catch a glimpse of their stars, wanting to see firsthand what ejection looked like. Inside there is a bubble of sorts, cameras and people living much like termites in the crawlspaces, filming and watching and servinv up whatever people want. A sickness has been travelling outside too, and this sickness seems to be getting worse. People are not exactly dying and, if you believe the hype, they are coming back from the dead. No worries, however, because Big Brother will continue - or maybe not.This originally aired a six pieces to a puzzle. They were lovely too, and they made me happy. In fact, when it comes to zombas (calling 'em zombies, but more like infected, really) and the way things happen, a lovely little fallout appeared on the reality TV horizon. It was the undead massing outside of the studios, ready to take people with them. I liked this alot, both on a personal level and on a zombie loving level, enjoying what might happen. You have FAST zombies and they have people trapped, ready to feed them to the - well, themselves. The wonder of that is that the people didn't want to fall over and dying. No, some wanted to fight.When it comes to these fighters, there are differences in them. you have the housemates a girlfriend and boyfriend tandum, a boss, as well as others being focused on. They are all different and they all bring something that the others do not have. Sometimes that is good and sometimes it is bad but it always seems entertaining. I personally laughed as the housemates learned what was going on the hard way, feeling like they deserved a bit of what transpired. and the ending - it was interesting and it was bleak.Lastly, there are some sexy zombies involved. Some die and some don't, but all of them do try running and eating. With no mama zombie to tell them not to run with their mouths full, they go to town sometimes, tearing through everything. I personally liked them and i liked the effects because they made something nice, shocking and surprising this watcher.It was a happy place.Anyone watching anything horror needs to watch this. The series is one of the BEST around and I loved it, thinking that it was the nice addition to The Walking Dead that was also on. The DVD is bare, running right into menus, but that is not much.5/5Also, watch the Region again.

reviewText: One of the best zombie miniseries ever! This is one you have to watch. I saw it first on IFC and when it was made available on Amazon I had to buy it. "Big Brother" meets "Night of the Living Dead" and the sole survivors are a group of people who couldn't get along long enough to screw in a light bulb...FANTASTIC! Well written and acted this show will have you on the edge of your seat! The special effects are what you might find in a big budget Hollywood zombie flick. Once again a foreign product has managed to nudge any domestic offering comletely out of the box (Except the Walking Dead on A&E of course). BRAVO!
